content.title: Choledocholithiasis
content.summary: Choledocholithiasis refers to stones in the common bile duct (CBD), which may be primary (formed in bile duct) or secondary (passed from gallbladder). It can cause biliary colic, obstructive jaundice, cholangitis, or pancreatitis. Management involves stone extraction via ERCP, followed by cholecystectomy to prevent recurrence.
key_points: 10-15% of gallstone patients have concurrent CBD stones
Can be asymptomatic or cause biliary colic, jaundice, cholangitis, pancreatitis
Diagnosis: Elevated bilirubin/ALP, dilated CBD (>6mm or >8mm post-cholecystectomy)
Risk stratification guides workup: MRCP for intermediate risk, direct ERCP for high risk
ERCP with sphincterotomy and stone extraction is gold standard treatment
Cholecystectomy should follow ERCP to prevent recurrent stones
content.statement: Choledocholithiasis presents with biliary obstruction signs and is diagnosed using liver tests and imaging, requiring ERCP for stone extraction and cholecystectomy to prevent recurrence.

explanation.intuition: Think of the bile duct as a plumbing pipe from the liver to the intestine. Stones can block this pipe, causing upstream pressure (jaundice, dilated ducts) and potential infection (cholangitis). ERCP is like a plumber's scope that goes up from the intestine to grab and remove the stone.
explanation.key_insight: Not all CBD stones need ERCP - risk stratification is key. Low probability: proceed to cholecystectomy with intraoperative cholangiogram. Intermediate probability: MRCP or EUS first to confirm stones before ERCP. High probability: proceed directly to ERCP. This approach minimizes unnecessary ERCPs and their complications.
explanation.technical_details: CBD normally ≤6mm (or ≤10mm post-cholecystectomy). Stones cause elevated conjugated bilirubin, ALP, GGT. Transabdominal ultrasound detects dilated CBD but misses 50% of stones. MRCP sensitivity 85-92% for stones. EUS sensitivity 94-97%. ERCP sensitivity 90%+ with therapeutic capability.

definitions_glossary.choledocholithiasis: Presence of stones in the common bile duct
definitions_glossary.common_bile_duct: CBD - duct carrying bile from liver/gallbladder to duodenum
definitions_glossary.primary_CBD_stone: Stone formed de novo in bile duct (usually brown pigment)
definitions_glossary.secondary_CBD_stone: Stone passed from gallbladder into CBD (usually cholesterol)
definitions_glossary.biliary_colic: Episodic RUQ pain from bile duct spasm/obstruction
definitions_glossary.obstructive_jaundice: Elevated conjugated bilirubin from bile flow obstruction
definitions_glossary.cholangitis: Bile duct infection; Charcot's triad: fever, jaundice, RUQ pain
definitions_glossary.sphincterotomy: Endoscopic incision of sphincter of Oddi to facilitate stone extraction
definitions_glossary.balloon_extraction: ERCP technique using balloon catheter to pull stones from CBD
definitions_glossary.biliary_stent: Plastic or metal tube placed to ensure bile drainage
definitions_glossary.MRCP: Magnetic resonance cholangiopancreatography - non-invasive bile duct imaging

pathophysiology.mechanism: Stones obstruct bile flow causing upstream biliary dilation, cholestatic liver injury, and potential bacterial infection (cholangitis) or pancreatic duct obstruction (pancreatitis)

secondary.origin: Gallbladder stones passing through cystic duct

primary.associations: Bile stasis, strictures, parasites, recurrent infections

clinical_presentation: Jaundice with dark urine and pale stools

imaging.transabdominal_US: First-line: CBD dilation, gallstones; misses 50% of CBD stones
imaging.EUS: 94-97% sensitivity; invasive but allows immediate ERCP if positive
imaging.ERCP: Diagnostic and therapeutic; reserved for high probability or treatment

differential_diagnosis: Acute cholecystitis (gallbladder wall thickening, Murphy's sign)
Mirizzi syndrome (cystic duct stone compressing CBD)

ERCP.large_stones: May require lithotripsy (mechanical, laser, or electrohydraulic)
ERCP.failed_extraction: Biliary stent placement for drainage, repeat ERCP

cholecystectomy.timing: Within same hospitalization if gallbladder in situ
cholecystectomy.rationale: Prevents recurrent CBD stones and cholecystitis
cholecystectomy.IOC: Intraoperative cholangiogram to detect residual stones

definition.@value: The presence of gallstones within the common bile duct, causing biliary obstruction and requiring endoscopic or surgical extraction

scopeNote.@value: Covers diagnosis, risk stratification, and management of CBD stones

medicalCode.description: Calculus of bile duct without cholangitis or cholecystitis

learning_objectives: Define choledocholithiasis and differentiate primary from secondary stones
Apply risk stratification to guide diagnostic approach
Describe ERCP technique for stone extraction
Recognize complications of untreated CBD stones
Explain the importance of cholecystectomy after ERCP
clinical_pearls: Normal CBD ≤6mm (add 1mm per decade over 60); >10mm is abnormal
Transabdominal US misses 50% of CBD stones - MRCP or EUS if high suspicion
Post-ERCP pancreatitis risk 3-5%; prophylactic rectal indomethacin reduces risk
Same-admission cholecystectomy reduces recurrent biliary events
Primary CBD stones (brown pigment) suggest underlying stricture or stasis
common_misconceptions: All patients with CBD stones need ERCP - low risk can proceed to surgery with IOC
Ultrasound is adequate for ruling out CBD stones - sensitivity only 50%
ERCP is risk-free - 3-5% pancreatitis rate requires careful risk/benefit
